title: Dave CEO, Jason Wilk: The Best Performing Fund Would Only Back YC Founders on Their Second Time

rawLines.text: $4 billion to $50 million market cap
today I have the founder of Dave one of
the US's leading NEO banks on the show
in 2022 they spacked and went public at
$4 billion excitement soon waned though
and their market cap dropped to just $50
million all of our PIPE investors from
our IPO bailed before our mockup expired
fintech became a bad word spa became a
bad word they lost an incredible 98% of
their value i had no support in my stock
we were we were but the
turnaround has been one of the best on
Wall Street they've increased market cap
by over 900% the investments again in AI
is really what led to a lot of the
profitability is there anything you
would have done differently about the
process honestly I don't regret going
out via spa i think we just went public
too late you went public too late i
think the company realistically was
ready to go public probably 6 to 12
months earlier and ready to go
jason dude it is such a pleasure to have
you on the show i've heard so many great
things from Imran and from Ash so thank
you for joining me man yeah thanks Harry
great to be here now I would love to
start you sold your first business for
$85 million reportedly i'm just always
oscillating on the fact that bluntly do
richer founders make better founders i
think this a lot with investors when you
think about it do richer founders make
better founders i'd say
yes you know I don't think it's the case

quite often if you were to have a blank

exited YC founder for their second

i remember meeting Eric Glimman from

he then founded RAMP a month later
another great example great example can
I ask what is that though is that like
the financial safety that comes from
having a first exit is that having seen

this company I started was in 2009 was

you're presenting at the YC um you know
batch announcement but it was so

wasn't even a result of Y cominator i
had to try and convince him and convince

capped my salary at $30,000 a year until

that's how different it was back then to
raise capital was that a good move do
you think like now that would be
considered like vulture VC i love Mark
you love Mark so I don't mean that badly
on him but that would be considered
really bad form was that actually
helpful there's no way that would happen
again today but honestly it was an
amazing forcing function to try and
build a profitable business and not

raised any capital beyond the seed round
as a result of that so it taught us just
a lot about persistence and perseverance
to try and come up with a scalable

and interesting enough the $30,000

it sort of led us to that and then Mark

interesting story why did you not do YC
for Dave you did it the first time why
not the second time we actually were
willing to do it the second time not
willing i mean we we would have liked to

a much smaller group mark Zuckerberg

it was this really intimate experience
but it was also a different time when

there's really no point in them going

but that's only a select few companies
if you can be one of those businesses
